div1.p: Agramonte describes his role with the Yellow Fever Commission. Included are autograph notes by Truby and Hench.

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 3, 1908
div1.opener:
Havana, July 3, 1908.
Maj. Jefferson R. Kean, U. S. Army,
Havana.
My dear Major Kean;
div1.p:
I beg to return to you, herein enclosed, the
Senate Report which you kindly allowed me to examine. At the same
time, I desire to make a few remarks in answer to your question, as
to whether I thought that justice had been done to me for the part
which I took in the demonstration of the mosquito-transmission-
theory in yellow fever.

Speaking sincerely, I must say, that had I not read the docu-
ment above referred to, I would not have believed that such flagrant
injustice could have been committed by parties who, because of their
official positions, if for no other reason, ought to have been incapable
of such an act.

The Report which I return herewith, contains numerous mis-
statements, unpardonable misrepresentations, inexplicable omissions
and absolutely fails to give me credit for my share in the work
which resulted in a manner so brilliant and far-reaching, for the
sole purpose of enhancing the value of the services rendered by my
colleagues in the same work.

The Report truthfully states that Major Reed's “duties re-
quired him to be in Washington the greater part of the time; but
falls far short of the truth when it adds that “the actual work...
......was carried on in Cuba by Major Carroll and Doctor Lazear”.

No indeed; I was there on the spot all the time. Carroll heard
about the result of the mosquito waork only after he recovered from
his attack of yellow fever, which latter was the outcome, not of
a definite purpose to become infected, on his part but of a mosquito
bite received by him when he was confident of its innocuousness.

It was on the day that Carroll fell sick that Lazear and I be-
came convinced that his mosquito bite had done its work and im-
mediately decided, unknown to Carroll, of course, to apply the same
mosquito, together with others, to the first man who presented him-
self and furnished sufficient evidence that he had not been within
the infected zone for several days. This man happened to be Ser-
geant Dean, who also unknown to Carroll, came down with yellow
fever while C. was in the acme of his attack. When Dr. Ames, great-
ly mystified, admitted that Dean's case was yellow fever, Lazear and
I decided to communicate with Major Reed who was then in Washington.

It is very easy to prove these facts by referring to the dates
on the official records.

Before Carroll's case, we had little confidence in the mosquito
theory. Carroll had absolutely none; he was thinking all the time
of an anaerobic organism as the etiologic agent of the disease,
which, he thought, presented great difficulties for its cultivation.
Reed and I were slightly inclined to the belief in some insect
agency, but Lazear was a convert from the early part of our work and
so soon as it became evident that the tissues in our autopsies were
practically sterile and contained no organisms. What inclined Reed
and myself to the insect theory were probably the following facts.

On the 27th of June 1900 I was ordered to Santa Clara, to in-
vestigate an epidemic of yellow fever which had been active in said
city; my inability to place the blame, the manner in which the epi-
demic extended and that in which cases developed in the Post Hospital,
led me to think of insect agency in the transmission of the dis-
ease. I remember having discussed the question with Capt. Stone,
(3)
Post Surgeon, at the time; Dr. Stone may remember the circumstance;
if not a convert, at least he was also inclined to believe in mos-
quitoes. After my return from this duty, the Board discussed for
the first time the possibility of mosquito infection.

During the month of July 1900, several suspicious cases oc-
curred at Pinar del Rio Barracks which were being diagnosed as per-
nicious malaria by the post surgeons. I was ordered, (July 27th,)
to investigate them and the same day of my arrival I reported an
epidemic of yellow fever at said station, against the opinion of the
Post Commander and four medical officers, who were there in charge
of the sick. Major Reed came to Pinar del Rio two days after and
there, on the ground, we studied together the possibility of all
methods of infection, we visited the sleeping quarters, an old
Spanish barrack, and endeavored to trace the facts which might ac-
cord with the mosquito theory sustained by Finlay. We knew nothing
of the writings of Beauperthuy at that time.

As I say above, Lazear was the only member of the Board who had
complete faith in the mosquito transmission of the disease; he had
obtained considerable experience while in Italy, within the study of
this insect, particularly in theirits breeding and microscopical ex-
amination. Neither Reed, Carroll or myself, at the time, could tell
the difference between Culex fasciatus and any other culex. For this
reason, Lazear undertook to make a study of mosquitoes, to breed,
them and if possible to infect them for microscopical investigation.

You know the consequences in the latter part of August. The
fortunate results in Carroll's and Dean's cases led Dr. Lazear to
believe that experimental yellow fever was absolutely safe: this
idea I combatted upon every opportunity, even as we stood by Carroll's
bed and watched him, in what seemed the agony of death. Lazear was
very fixed in his opinions and once having formed one, it was
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
(4)
very difficult to make him change it; as we know, a few days after
the recovery of Dean, he allowed himself to be bitten by a mosquito
which escaped him, undoubtedly causing his infection and subsequent
death.

When at Lazear's call, Major Reed came and saw what had
been accomplished, we decided to prepare the “Preliminary Note”
which he rushed away to Indiannapolis, to read, before the American
Medical Association, (Oct. 22-26, 1900.)

It was decided that Carroll should take a short rest after his
attack of yellow fever and as it was considered unsafe to keep in-
fected mosquitoes at Camp Columbia, the duty of infecting and keep-
ing them fell to me, who was at the same time in charge of the De-
partment Laboratory at Hospital No. 1, from where 1 carried them to
Las Animas Hospitals for infection and later to Camp Lazear for
inoculation. I have copy of the military orders pertaining to these
data.

It was at the Department Laboratory that the real mosquito work
was initiated; while breeding and studying the various varieties, I
found the first anopheles described in Cuba, which to-day appears
under the name of Nyssorhyneus cubensis, (Agramonte 1900,) in Prof.
Blanchard's latest work “Les Moustiques”. I also found out the
valuable work of the common Cuban fresh water fish “Gambusiae,” in
devouring the larvae of mosquitoes, etc. etc.

I have in my possession a complete record of the mosquitoes
bred, infected and applied by me from the 6th of October 1900, to January 1901,
in which record appears numerous notes made by Maj. Reed during
said period and which testify to my active part in the work of the
Board.

The enclosed Report, in that part cited from Senate Document
No. 118, Fifty Seventh Congress, second session, goes on to say
that Reed's attention was called to Carter's report of the Ormond,
Miss. cases before the first cases of the Board; the fact is that
Reed's and the Board's attention was attracted to Carter's paper
at the time we were preparing the Preliminary Note and not before.
At that time, the Board did not ask any support from General Wood,
as it is further misstated; this was done later, after Major Reed
returned from Indiannapolis and we felt the necessity of establish-
ing an experimental camp.

But the grossest injustice and misrepresentation is found in
that paragraph where it says “The fourth member of the Boards Com-
mission, Dr. Agramonte, did not participate in the mosquito work
of the commission until a later date, nor did he share their danger,
as he was a Cuban and a non-immune”.
I would like to know where was I all the time?

It would be highly improper to refer in these lines to petty
differences which might have existed between some of the members of
the Board, but in my own defence I may be allowed to state that Dr.
Lazear and I were upon particularly intimate terms; we were class-
mates, having graduated at the same time from the College of Physic-
ians and Surgeons, New York, in 1892. Take note, that he it was who
made the inoculations upon Carroll and Dean, that Carroll did not
know, until his convalescence, where he obtained his infection and
further, that Reed was in Washington at the time, so that Lazear and
I were the only members of the Board present at the first demonstrat-
ion. Can any one believe, under the circumstances, that I took no
part in the mosquito work of the commission until a later date? If
any attempt had been made, and surely Lazear would not have made it
to exclude me from participating in the work, we, (you and I,) are kno
sufficiently acquainted with Major Reed's character to know that
he would have never consented it.

When the Board first met in Cuba, the work was distributed so
that Lazear attended to the pathological work, Carroll the bacterio-
logical and I performed all the autopsies. Maj. Reed remained as
Director. When Reed returned, the experimental camp was established
and the “mosquito house” was built, I brought all my mosquitoes from
the Department Laboratory and turned them over to Carroll for their
care. It became my duty then to obtain the Spaniards for the ino-
culations and to perform these, both by mosquito bite and blood in-
jection, until the breaking up of the Camp, after the meeting of
the Third Pan-American Medical Congress in February 1901.

The “memorandum” prepared by Surgeon General O'Reilly and
which appears in the Report, comes nearer to the truth, yet in his
evident desire to favor Carroll and Lazear for the very laudable
purpose of securing a pension for their widows, he forgets the
“fourth” member of the Board, which was “third”, by the way, and
not fourth, in the order of their appointment. Referring to the
demonstration on the first cases, it says, “these three cases es-
tablished in the minds of Reed and Carroll the proof of the mosquito
theory and formed the basis of their paper, “The Etiology of Yellow
fever, (Preliminary Note.”

I would ask Gen. O'Reilly whether my name does not appear as
part author of that paper? Or was I to be considered as dead as
our colleague Lazear, whose a name by the way, was added at my per-
sistent indication? Do you think this fair justice on the part of
your Surgeon General? Can he claim ignorance, do you think?

In the same vein run the final paragraphs of this memorandum,
in which the Surgeon General forgets to write my name in connection
with the Board of which no one can deny I was an integral part,
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
(7)
much as they may be little, for their own purpose, the share I am
entitled to in the honor of its acchievements.

I am striving by dint of constant work, study and unswerving
devotion to duty as I see it, that when the time comes for me to
take the welcome leap into the Great Unknown, my wife and child
may need no pension from the political powers that may be; but if
I am so unfortunate as to fail in this undertaking and they be com-
pelled to resort to the Government in quest of the means wherewith
to support life, it is my wish that they claim for the purpose the
glory and honor that may be actually due to me for the work that I
may have accomplished, and to refrain from decrying that performed
by my colleagues, as it has been done by their friends in may case.

I thank you again for the opportunity afforded to read the Re-
port and remain
